outputs.output_descr: The Project is to build mechanisms to effectively facilitate the integration of the Peace and Development Analysis findings into development planning frameworks at the national, oblast and local levels.  Using local civil society partners, strengthen the skill base of a variety of actors  such as key central government officials, parliamentarians, representatives from oblast and local authority, and other civic leaders on conflict prevention, conflict sensitive development, and collaborative decision-making, through a targeted package of experiential training, and mentoring. Particular attention will be paid to ensure the participation of women leaders in this capacity development effort at both the national and local levels. The Project is also to strengthen the capacity of the media for conflict sensitive and objective reporting, including on the issues emerging from the Peace and Development Analysis process.

A key focus of the UNDP Peace and Development Programme is the Peace and Development Analysis (PDA). The PDA is a development planning tool that assists all actors, including women, youth and ethnic minorities, to jointly and formally establish a common vision of peace and development in Kyrgyzstan. The PDA process brings together people from all sectors and levels of the Kyrgyz Republic and is a participatory, multi-stakeholder process that helps government, civil society and development actors to analyze the local context from different points of view.

The Project will build on its previous cross border work and will strengthen existing as well as create new joint working groups at the district level of bordering areas of Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and as possible Uzbekistan.  These districts will be identified during the Peace and Development Analysis and membership of the groups will be developed together by UNDP and its local partners.  These groups will be under the chairmanship of each of the District Heads on rotational basis.  The groups will discuss and resolve cross-border issues with the involvement of local experts as needed.  Membership would include District Heads, Heads of municipalities within the districts, experts from relevant fields depending on the issue being discussed, law enforcement structures and representatives of local women groups to ensure some semblance of gender balance.  The principle of gender balance will also be followed whenever possible when selecting participants for membership in the working groups. The Project will continue to work closely with UNDP Tajikistan to identify actors and to create and support the working groups.  The Programme also hopes to establish a similar relationship of cooperation with UNDP Uzbekistan.

Actions:
• Organize peace and development analysis in focus zones                                                                                        
• Do field research in focus zones                                                                                               
• Facilitate sessions on discussion, resolution/addressing cross border issues                                                                                    • Provide technical support to cross border working groups                             
• Support projects of trans-border communities focused on conflict prevention

Actions:
• Purchase of equipment for cross-border working groups  towards sustainability of cross-border working groups
